    Highlights

    •
    Mechanisms of membrane assembly during autophagosome biogenesis were discovered
    •
    Acyl-CoA synthetase Faa1 channels fatty acids into de novo phospholipid synthesis
    •
    Newly synthesized phospholipids specifically drive phagophore expansion
    •
    Description of the phospholipid composition of purified autophagic membranes

    Summary

    Autophagy is a conserved catabolic homeostasis process central for cellular and organismal health. During autophagy, small single-membrane phagophores rapidly expand into large double-membrane autophagosomes to encapsulate diverse cargoes for degradation. It is thought that autophagic membranes are mainly derived from preformed organelle membranes. Instead, here we delineate a pathway that expands the phagophore membrane by localized phospholipid synthesis. Specifically, we find that the conserved acyl-CoA synthetase Faa1 accumulates on nucleated phagophores and locally activates fatty acids (FAs) required for phagophore elongation and autophagy. Strikingly, using isotopic FA tracing, we directly show that Faa1 channels activated FAs into the synthesis of phospholipids and promotes their assembly into autophagic membranes. Indeed, the first committed steps of de novo phospholipid synthesis at the ER, which forms stable contacts with nascent autophagosomes, are essential for autophagy. Together, our work illuminates how cells spatially tune synthesis and flux of phospholipids for autophagosome biogenesis during autophagy.

    Graphical Abstract

    Keywords

    1. autophagy
    2. autophagosome biogenesis

    4. membrane composition
    5. Acyl-CoA synthetase

    One level at which cells regulate lipid fluxes is constituted by a conserved protein family of long-chain acyl-CoA synthetases (ACSs), which catalyzes the activation of fatty acids (FAs) by ATP hydrolysis-driven thioesterification of free FAs with coenzyme A (CoA). ACSs form complex networks composed of peripheral and transmembrane proteins (6 in yeast and 13 in mammals). Based on their dynamic and differential subcellular localization, ACSs are thought to channel activated FAs into diverse pathways including lipid synthesis, membrane editing, protein acylation, and vesicular fusion (Black and DiRusso, 2007; Coleman, 2019; Digel et al., 2009; Grevengoed et al., 2014; Watkins et al., 2007

    Faa1 Is Critical for Autophagy Flux

    Our observations raised the possibility of a direct function of ACSs in autophagy.     Human ACSL4 Localizes to Autophagic Membranes and Drives Autophagy in Yeast

    We asked whether ACS function in autophagy is evolutionarily conserved. High complexity of mammalian ACS systems, consisting of up to 13 protein isoforms, poses a major challenge to conclusively evaluate direct functions of individual ACSs in vivo (Coleman, 2019; Grevengoed et al., 2014
    11.
    Coleman, R.A.

Only ACSL4v1 detectably expressed and promoted survival of Δfaa1Δfaa3Δfaa4 cells (Figure S2G). Thus, the capacity of ACSs to localize to nascent autophagosomes and regulate autophagy is evolutionarily conserved from yeast to human.

    Local Catalytic Activity of Faa1 Drives Autophagy

    ACSs are thought to channel FA fluxes based on dynamic subcellular localization and local activity. To test this concept for autophagy, we first examined whether the catalytic activity of Faa1 on autophagic membranes was required for autophagy. Expression of plasmid-encoded mCherry-tagged FAA1 restored autophagy flux in PM-FAA1 cells during starvation and FAS-inhibition (Figures 3A–3C). In contrast, expression of the catalytically inactive variants, faa1Y269A and faa1E460A, both defective in ATP and AMP binding, or faa1W533A, which is compromised in FA binding, did not promote autophagy flux, even though both WT and catalytically inactive Faa1 localized to autophagic membranes (Figures 3A–3C) (Black and DiRusso, 2007; Black et al., 1997; Weimar et al., 2002

    Faa1-Mediated FA Channeling Promotes Autophagosome Biogenesis

    Given that the autophagy machinery was only minimally affected in PM-FAA1 cells, we reasoned that phagophore-bound Faa1 may function directly in autophagosome biogenesis. To test this hypothesis, we analyzed the behavior of 2GFP-Atg8-marked autophagic structures in FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells with fluorescence microscopy. Fixed time point analysis suggested that PM-FAA1 cells were capable of forming autophagosomes, albeit at a slightly lower steady-state level and reduced size compared with FAA1 cells after 3 h of starvation and FAS-inhibition (Figures S5A–S5C), despite the severe autophagy defects under this condition. Thus, to accurately assess the dynamic nature of autophagosome biogenesis, we monitored autophagic structures in FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells by time-lapse imaging during starvation and FAS-inhibition. In FAA1 cells, we observed multiple, often simultaneous events of autophagosome formation (∼3 events/cell/30 min): newly formed punctate Atg8-structures expanded in circumference or, occasionally, in a rod-shaped manner and formed ring-like autophagosomes, which disappeared after a few minutes due to Atg8 deconjugation and vacuole fusion (arrowheads, Figure 4A). Strikingly, in PM-FAA1 cells, we detected several Atg8-puncta (∼3 events/cell/30 min), which vanished quickly without displaying membrane expansion comparable to FAA1 cells (arrows; Figure 4A). In addition, the rate of formation of ring-like autophagosomes was significantly reduced in PM-FAA1 cells (1 event/cell/30 min; Figure 4A). These data indicated that nucleated phagophores often failed to expand and only seldomly formed autophagosomes in the absence of local FA activation. To explore whether detectable ring-like autophagosomes that did form in PM-FAA1 cells were also affected, we measured the duration of only completed events of autophagosome biogenesis. Autophagic membranes are marked by Faa1 past Atg8 deconjugation independently of its catalytic activity (Figures 1D and 3B) and, thus, in combination with Atg8, allowed us to trace the complete process of autophagosome formation. Time-lapse analysis comparing PM-FAA1 cells coexpressing 2GFP-ATG8 and plasmid-encoded FAA1- or catalytically inactive faa1Y269A-mCherry revealed a significant increase in the time it took for punctate structures to evolve into ring-like autophagosome in the absence of local FA activation; both the time period of Faa1- and Atg8-positive membranes (9.2 ± 0.1 versus 20.3 ± 1.9 min, yellow) and of predominantly Faa1-positive autophagosomes after Atg8 deconjugation (0.4 ± 0.02 versus 3.4 ± 1.0 min, red) were significantly extended in faa1Y269A-expressing cells (Figures 4B and 4C). Thus, impaired local FA activation by Faa1 significantly delayed the biogenesis of detectable ring-like autophagosomes. Of note, the slow forming autophagosomes in PM-FAA1 cells rarely fused with the vacuole, or at least not in a productive manner, given we barely detected any inner autophagosomal vesicles in the lumen of Δpep4 by electron or fluorescence microscopy after starvation and FAS-inhibition (Figures 2E and S5D) (Takeshige et al., 1992
    95.
    Takeshige, K. ∙ Baba, M. ∙ Tsuboi, S. ...
    Autophagy in yeast demonstrated with proteinase-deficient mutants and conditions for its induction
    J. Cell Biol. 1992; 119:301-311
    Crossref
    Scopus (816)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In summary, these data indicate a critical role for local FA activation by Faa1 for efficient expansion of nucleated phagophores and autophagosome biogenesis.

    Faa1-Mediated FA Channeling Specifically Drives Phagophore Expansion

    To directly measure the dynamic behavior of phagophores in dependence of local Faa1 activity, we followed autophagic membranes by time-lapse imaging upon inducible overexpression of selective autophagy cargo, blue fluorescent protein (BFP)-tagged prApe1 (Suzuki et al., 2013
    94.
    Suzuki, K. ∙ Akioka, M. ∙ Kondo-Kakuta, C. ...
    Fine mapping of autophagy-related proteins during autophagosome formation in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
    J. Cell Sci. 2013; 126:2534-2544
    Crossref
    Scopus (176)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In FAA1 cells, phagophores nucleated as punctate Atg8 structures and then expanded laterally, forming spherical caps on the surface of giant prApe1 oligomers during starvation and FAS-inhibition. Phagophores reached a maximal size at which they only partially encapsulated the cargo and Atg8 signals declined (Figure 5A), indicating a limit to phagophore growth consistent with previous data (Suzuki et al., 2013
    94.
    Suzuki, K. ∙ Akioka, M. ∙ Kondo-Kakuta, C. ...
    Fine mapping of autophagy-related proteins during autophagosome formation in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
    J. Cell Sci. 2013; 126:2534-2544
    Crossref
    Scopus (176)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Thus, this assay enabled us to clearly distinguish phagophore nucleation (puncta) and expansion (spherical caps) morphologically and to assess key parameters of phagophore dynamics quantitatively. Consistent with intact phagophore nucleation, we detected the same number of phagophores at giant prApe1 oligomers in FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells, on average 1.5 ± 0.04 and 1.5 ± 0.3 Atg8 structures, respectively, during the time frame of the experiment. For FAA1 cells, we determined that punctate phagophores expanded with a frequency of over 80% and a growth rate of ∼0.4 μm2/min up to a maximal size of ∼5.3 μm2 (Figures 5A–5D). However, in PM-FAA1 cells, the expansion frequency was significantly reduced to ∼44%, and a majority of phagophores remained in a punctate state without discernable lateral growth over time (Figures 5A and 5B), confirming the expansion defects we observed without prApe1 overexpression (Figure 4A). Phagophores that did expand grew at a significantly lower rate of ∼0.2 μm2/min and to a smaller maximal size of ∼4.0 μm2 on average in PM-FAA1 cells compared with expanding phagophores in FAA1 cells (Figures 5C and 5D), suggesting that the delayed formation of ring-like autophagosomes described in Figure 4B is caused by slowed membrane growth. Thus, these data clearly show that Faa1-mediated FA channeling functions downstream of phagophore nucleation and is specifically required for the efficient expansion of the phagophore.
    We asked whether FA partitioning by Faa1 constituted a rate-limiting step for phagophore dynamics. To test this hypothesis, we supplemented growth and starvation media with oleate (C18:1) to increase the available FA pool in starving cells. Interestingly, we observed significantly increased autophagy flux in FAA1 cells in the presence of oleate during starvation and FAS-inhibition (Figure 5E), consistent with previous data in mammalian cells (Dupont et al., 2014
    15.
    Dupont, N. ∙ Chauhan, S. ∙ Arko-Mensah, J. ...
    Neutral lipid stores and lipase PNPLA5 contribute to autophagosome biogenesis
    Curr. Biol. 2014; 24:609-620
    Full Text
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (127)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Importantly, added FAs promoted autophagy flux in a strictly Faa1-dependent manner, because PM-FAA1 cells where unaffected by oleate supplementation (Figure 5E). When we monitored phagophore dynamics on giant prApe1 oligomers, we found that the addition of oleate increased the number of phagophores in the same manner in FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells, 2.0 ± 0.2 and 1.9 ± 0.2, respectively, suggesting that phagophore nucleation occurs in a generally Faa1-independent manner. Interestingly, the absolute and relative frequency of phagophore expansion significantly increased in FAA1 cells but remained low in PM-FAA1 cells in the presence of oleate (Figures 5A and 5B), indicating that the transitioning of phagophores into expansion is determined by Faa1-mediated local FA activation. Importantly, while the maximal phagophore size in FAA1 or PM-FAA1 cells did not significantly change (Figure 5D), oleate supplementation accelerated the growth of phagophore membranes specifically in FAA1 cells to a significantly higher rate (∼0.6 μm2/min) compared with PM-FAA1 cells (∼0.3 μm2/min; Figures 5A and 5C). Taken together, these data demonstrate that Faa1-mediated FA channeling regulates the propensity of phagophores to transition into expansion and determines the growth rate of autophagic membranes in a rate-limiting manner during phagophore expansion.

    Autophagic Membrane Composition Is Unaffected by Local Faa1 Activity

    To uncover the mechanistic underpinnings of Faa1-regulated phagophore dynamics, we explored the phospholipid composition of cellular and autophagic membranes. Using mass spectrometry, we first analyzed the phospholipidome of whole FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells. Interestingly, we observed that cells substantial remodeled the phospholipid headgroup and FA composition after exposure to starvation and FAS inhibition (Figures 6A and 6B). For example, starving cells strongly increased the relative PI content from 12% in log-phase to 46% during starvation, while there was a simultaneous decrease in phosphatidylcholine (PC) and phosphatidylethanolamine (PE) levels (Figures 6A and 6B). In parallel, cellular FA profiles of phospholipids shifted toward a higher content of unsaturated and longer FAs in starving cells (Figures 6A and 6B). Importantly, the remodeling of the cellular phospholipidome occurred in both FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells in a similar manner during starvation (Figures 6A and 6B), indicating that global alterations in the cellular phospholipid composition are unlikely to cause the autophagy defects of PM-FAA1 cells.
    Next, we focused our efforts on analyzing the phospholipid composition of autophagic membranes. The lipid composition of autophagosomes has been undefined. Thus, we established a method to coimmunoprecipitate autophagic membranes covalently bound to 2GFP-Atg8 (referred to as Atg8 membranes) from FAA1 cells and, as controls, from FAA1 cells that were either deficient in vacuolar fusion (Δypt7) or Atg8 lipidation (Δatg7) (Figures S6A and S6B) (Haas et al., 1995; Huang et al., 2000; Ichimura et al., 2000; Tanida et al., 1999

Interestingly, compared to whole cell membranes, Atg8 membranes showed highly unsaturated FA profiles, consistent with previous observations (Reunanen et al., 1985
    85.
    Reunanen, H. ∙ Punnonen, E.L. ∙ Hirsimäki, P.
    Studies on vinblastine-induced autophagocytosis in mouse liver. V. A cytochemical study on the origin of membranes
    Histochemistry. 1985; 83:513-517

    ). Around 60% of phospholipids contained two unsaturated FA residues (two double bonds), while only 2% carried two saturated FA moieties (0 double bonds) (Figures 6B and 6C, middle and bottom panels). FA desaturation increases membrane fluidity. Thus, our data indicate a FA composition of autophagic membranes highly conducive to dynamic phagophore behavior and shape. However, neither relative headgroup nor FA composition of Atg8 membranes differed significantly between FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells (Figure 6C), revealing that phagophores and autophagosomes that formed slowly in PM-FAA1 cells consisted of membranes with similar composition as in FAA1 cells. We reasoned that, although FA channeling by phagophore-bound Faa1 accelerated the expansion of phagophores, PM-tethered Faa1 may generate a compositionally similar pool of activated FAs albeit with lower local concentration. In conclusion, these data indicate that the differences in phagophore dynamics are not due to differences in autophagic membrane composition.

    Faa1 Partitions FA into Phospholipid Synthesis and Assembly of Autophagic Membranes

    We reasoned that Faa1 may accumulate on nucleated phagophores in order to partition FA precursors locally into de novo phospholipid synthesis to generate a lipid source for efficient phagophore expansion. To directly test this model, we analyzed FA fluxes in vivo, using stable isotope tracing in combination with high-resolution mass spectrometry. We added 13C-labeled palmitoleate (13C16:1) or 13C-labeled oleate (13C18:1) to FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells for 30 min after 2.5 h of starvation and FAS inhibition and harvested cells for whole cell lipidomics. To assess the contribution of autophagy, we also tracked isotopic FAs in FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells blocked for autophagosome biogenesis (Δatg1). We observed significant incorporation of both isotopic FAs into the major double-unsaturated PC, PE, and PI species in FAA1 cells (Figures 6D and 6E). Consistent with Faa1-dependent local FA partitioning into de novo phospholipid synthesis, isotopic FA incorporation was significantly reduced in PM-FAA1 cells compared with FAA1 cells (Figures 6D and 6E). Inhibition of autophagosome biogenesis in FAA1Δatg1 cells caused an overall moderate reduction in phospholipid synthesis compared with FAA1 cells (Figure 6D). Intriguingly, it specifically lowered the incorporation rate for single-labeled PC and PI species, which are also major constituents of Atg8 membranes, to a similar extent as in PM-FAA1 cells (Figures 6C and 6E), suggesting that autophagosome biogenesis, at least in parts, is coordinated with phospholipid synthesis. In keeping with this notion, the incorporation of isotopic FAs in PM-FAA1 cells was strongly reduced further in PM-FAA1Δatg1 cells (Figures 6D and 6E), suggesting that residual autophagosome biogenesis is largely responsible for the remaining phospholipid synthesis in PM-FAA1 cells (Figures 6D and 6E). Taken together, these data indicate that Faa1-mediated FA channeling and autophagosome biogenesis coordinately regulate de novo phospholipid synthesis during starvation.
    Next, we directly tested whether newly synthesized phospholipids are incorporated into autophagic membranes. For this, we tracked isotopic FAs specifically in autophagic membranes by isolating Atg8 membranes from FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells after pulse labeling as described above. Strikingly, we detected significantly reduced isotopic FA incorporation into a broad spectrum of phospholipids of Atg8 membranes in PM-FAA1 cells compared with FAA1 cells (Figures 6D and 6F). Moreover, we found that Atg8 membranes incorporated newly synthesized phospholipids at a higher rate on average compared with whole cell membranes after tracing isotopic FAs in FAA1 cells for 5, 15, or 30 min and performing lipidomics in parallel on whole cell and isolated Atg8 membranes (Figure 6G). Taken together, these data strongly support the model that the localized activity of Faa1 on nucleated phagophores partitions FAs into the de novo synthesis of phospholipids, which are preferentially assembled into autophagic membranes.

    De Novo Phospholipid Synthesis Is Essential for Phagophore Expansion and Autophagy

    Our model predicted that de novo synthesis is required for autophagy by providing phospholipids for membrane growth during phagophore expansion. To test this hypothesis, we examined the functional relevance of the two initial and committed steps for de novo phospholipid synthesis. Acyl-CoAs are incorporated into glycerol-3-phosphate or dihydroxyacetone-phosphate by the acyltransferases Gpt2 and Sct1, and, in the next step, into 1-acyl-gylcerol-3-phosphate by the acyltransferases Ale1 and Slc1 to produce phosphatidic acid (PA), the precursor for all major phospholipids (Figure 7A)(Athenstaedt and Daum, 1997; Benghezal et al., 2007; Henry et al., 2012; Jain et al., 2007; Riekhof et al., 2007; Zheng and Zou, 2001

    Discussion

    Here, we have identified the molecular mechanisms underlying the rapid and extensive membrane expansion during autophagosome biogenesis. Our study is consistent with prior work indicating that phagophores nucleate from mainly preexisting membranes contributed by Atg9 and COPII vesicles orchestrated by core autophagy machinery (Davis et al., 2016; Ge et al., 2013, 2014, 2017; Graef et al., 2013; Ishihara et al., 2001; Karanasios et al., 2016; Longatti et al., 2012; Mari et al., 2010; Puri et al., 2018; Shima et al., 2019; Suzuki et al., 2013; Yamamoto et al., 2012; Young et al., 2006; Zoppino et al., 2010

    Why does autophagosome biogenesis rely on de novo phospholipid synthesis?     Our work describes the phospholipid composition of autophagic membranes characterized by a high degree of desaturation conducive to highly dynamic phagophore properties.     Experimental Model and Subject Details

    Yeast Strains and Media

    All strains used in this study are derivatives of Saccharomyces cerevisiae w303 and are listed in Table S1. PCR-based targeted homologous recombination was used to obtain gene deletions by replacing complete ORFs by indicated cassettes as described previously (Sheff and Thorn, 2004
    88.
    Sheff, M.A. ∙ Thorn, K.S.
    Optimized cassettes for fluorescent protein tagging in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
    Yeast. 2004; 21:661-670

    Scopus (436)

    ), or to modify genes to express functional C-terminally tagged variants using pFA6a-link-yEGFP-CaURA3, pFA6a-link-3yEGFP-CaURA3, pFA6a-link-mCherry-kanMX6, pFA6a-link-mCherry-HIS3, pHyg-AIDx-6HA as described previously (Graef et al., 2013; Morawska and Ulrich, 2013
    26.
    Graef, M. ∙ Friedman, J.R. ∙ Graham, C. ...

    An expanded tool kit for the auxin-inducible degron system in budding yeast
    Yeast. 2013; 30:341-351

    ). FAA1 or PM-FAA1 strains were generated by replacing the FAA1 ORF with FAA1 (1-2100 bp) or a fusion of the SLM1 pleckstrin homology (PH)-domain (1402-1743 bp) and FAA1 (4-2100 bp) both linked to kanMX6 cassettes (pFA6a-kanMX6) in Δatg19::natMX6/hphMX6 Δfaa3::TRP1 Δfaa4::HIS3 strain backgrounds.
    Strains were grown in synthetic complete medium (0.7% (w/v) yeast nitrogen base (BD Difco) and 2% (w/v) α-D-glucose (Sigma)) or synthetic medium lacking respective amino acids for plasmid selection at 30°C. For starvation, cells were harvested from early log-phase, washed 5 times and resuspended in SD-N medium (0.17% (w/v) yeast nitrogen base without amino acids and ammonium sulfate (BD Difco) and 2% (w/v) α-D-glucose (Sigma)) ± cerulenin (50 μg/mL; Sigma). SD-N-Glc contained α-D-glucose (0.01% (Sigma)). For fatty acid supplementation experiments, cells were grown in synthetic complete medium containing 0.1 mM oleic acid (C18:1, Sigma; dissolved in 5:1 (v/v) ethanol/tyloxapol (Merck/Sigma)) until log phase, washed 5 times and resuspended in SD-N medium containing 50 μg/mL cerulenin and 0.1 mM oleic acid. For stable isotope labeling, cells were starved in SD-N medium + cerulenin with oleic acid or palmitoleic acid (13C18:1 or 13C16:1 with all carbons labeled, Sigma; dissolved in 5:1 (v/v) ethanol/tyloxapol (Merck/Sigma)) at a final concentration of 0.01 mM for either 5, 15 or 30 min followed by cell harvest and sample processing. For auxin-inducible-degron (AID-tag) dependent protein degradation, early log phase cells were grown in SD medium containing 100 μM 1-naphthaleneacetic acid (Sigma) for 3 h at 30°C, washed 5 times and resuspended in SD-N medium + cerulenin ± 100 μM 1-naphthaleneacetic acid. Rapamycin (400 ng/mL; Calbiochem) was added to media as indicated. To monitor the multivesicular body (MVB) pathway, cells expressing plasmid-encoded MUP1-GFP (pMG3) were grown in synthetic media without methionine prior to starvation as described in (Menant et al., 2006
    65.
    Menant, A. ∙ Barbey, R. ∙ Thomas, D.

    Crossref
    Scopus (36)

    Google Scholar
    ). To monitor the multivesicular body (MVB) pathway at auxin-inducible-degron (AID-tag) dependent protein degradation, early log phase cells were grown in synthetic media without methionine containing 300 μM 1-naphthaleneacetic acid (Sigma) for 3 h at 30°C, washed 5 times and resuspended in SD-N medium + cerulenin + 300 μM 1-naphthaleneacetic acid. To visualize vacuoles by fluorescence microscopy, FM4-64 was added at a final concentration of 0.1% (v/v) (ThermoFisher) to the media.

    Method Details

    Plasmids

    All plasmids were generated by “gap repair”-PCR-based targeted recombination in yeast as described previously (Oldenburg et al., 1997
    76.
    Oldenburg, K.R. ∙ Vo, K.T. ∙ Michaelis, S. ...
    Recombination-mediated PCR-directed plasmid construction in vivo in yeast
    Nucleic Acids Res. 1997; 25:451-452
    Crossref
    Scopus (0)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ) and are listed in Table S2. Briefly, plasmids pRS315 or pRS316 were linearized using endonucleases BamHI and HindIII and co-transformed with PCR fragments flanked by ≥ 40 bp homologous sequences (pRS315/6 sequences: 5′-GGCCAGTGAATTGTAATACGACTCACTATAGGGCGAATTG-3′; 5′-CAAGCT CGGAATTAACCCTCACTAAAGGGAACAAAAGCTG-3′). For pMG3 and pMG27, prMUP1-MUP1 (−886 to 1722 bp) was combined in frame with either yEGFP-CaURA3- or mCherry-kanMX6 (forward: 5′-GGTGACGGTGCTGGTTTA-3′; backward: 5′-TCGATGAATTCGAGCTCG-3′) derived from pFA6a-yEGFP-CaURA3 or pFA6a-mCherry-kanMX6 respectively. pMG4 was generated by combining the ADH1-promoter (prADH1: −379 to −1 bp), yEGFP (1-711 bp; pFA6a-yEGFP-CaURA3), linker (link42: 5′-GGTGCT GGTGCTAACATTTTAGGTGCTGGTGACGGTGGTGCT-3′), and yEGFP-CaURA3. pMG5-pMG8 were obtained from prFAA1-FAA1 (−1000 to 2100 bp; faa1-Y269A: T805G, A806C; faa1-E460A: A1379C, G1380T; faa1-W533A: T1597G, G1598C, G1599T), and mCherry-kanMX6 (forward: 5′-GGTGACGGTGCTGGTTTA-3′; backward: 5′-TCGATGAATTCG AGCTCG-3′ derived from pFA6a-mCherry-kanMX6). pMG9-pMG15 were constructed by combining prVAC8-VAC8 (−1000 to 1734 bp), prSEC24-SEC24 (−1000 to 2778 bp), prSEC61-SEC61 (−1000 to 1440 bp), or prICE2-ICE2 (−1000 to 1473 bp) with linker (link42), FAA1 or faa1-Y269A (1 to 2100 bp), and mCherry-kanMX6 (Malcova et al., 2016
    63.
    Malcova, I. ∙ Farkasovsky, M. ∙ Senohrabkova, L. ...
    New integrative modules for multicolor-protein labeling and live-cell imaging in Saccharomyces cerevisiae
    FEMS Yeast Res. 2016; 16
    Crossref
    Scopus (10)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). The plasmid pMG24 was derived from the centromeric plasmid pMG23 and cloned into the multicopy vector pRS425 after linearization using endonucleases BamHI and HindIII. For pMG25 and pMG26 ACSL4 splice variant 1 (ACSL4v1) from H. sapiens (1-2010 bp) (pcDNA-ACSL4v1-eGFP; OHu2430c; Genscript) was fused to either 3xyeGFP-CaURA3 or mCherry-kanMX6 under control of FAA1 promoter (−1000 to −1 bp).

    Cell viability

    After incubating cells in 0.2% (v/v) trypan blue (Sigma) for 5 min and five washes with 1xPBS (Phosphate Buffered Saline, GIBCO), cell viability was assessed by brightfield microscopy and expressed as the ratio of blue-stained (dead) and unstained (viable) cells.

    Fluorescence microscopy

    Cells were transferred to 96-well glass bottom microplates (Greiner Bio-One) containing indicated media. For fixed time point analyses, cells were imaged at room temperature with an inverted microscope (Nikon Ti-E) using a Plan Apochromat IR 60x 1.27 NA objective (Nikon) and Spectra X LED light source (Lumencor). Three-dimensional light microscopy data were collected using the triggered Z-Piezo system (Nikon) and orca flash 4.0 camera (Hamamatsu). Three-dimensional data were processed using NIS-elements AR (Nikon), Huygens Professional 16.10 (Scientific Volume Imaging) and Photoshop (Adobe Systems, San Jose, CA) software. Data are shown as single sections. Time-lapse analyses were performed at 30°C with an inverted microscope (Visitron CSU-X1; Zeiss) using an alpha-Plan Apochromat 100x 1.46 NA oil immersion objective (Zeiss) and orca flash 4.0 V2 digital camera (Hamamatsu). High-speed confocal imaging was performed at 30°C with a Dragonfly 500 series microscope (Andor, Oxford instruments) equipped with a Zyla 4.2 Plus sCMos camera (Andor) using a Lamba CFI-Plan Apochromat 100x 1.45 NA oil immersion objective (Nikon). Three-dimensional data were processed using Fusion software (Andor), and ImageJ Version 2.0.0.

    Measuring phagophore dynamics

    FAA1 and PM-FAA1 cells expressing 2GFP-ATG8 and harboring pRS425-prCUP1-APE1-prAPE1-tagBFP-APE1 were harvested at early log-phase, resuspended in SD medium containing 250 μM CuSO4 (Roth) and incubated for 3 h at 30°C. Cells were pelleted, washed 5 times and resuspended in starvation medium containing 50 μg/mL cerulenin. After 2 h 45 min of starvation, cells were imaged by fluorescence microscopy and Z stacks were recorded for 24 time points at 2 min intervals. To determine expansion frequency of phagophores, punctate Atg8 structures formed at giant preApe1 oligomers were followed over time and scored as “nonexpanding” in the absence of lateral growth. For growth rate and maximal size determination, phagophores were treated as spherical caps forming on spherical giant preApe1 oligomers. Using line diagrams in ImageJ (Version 2.0.0), diameters of giant preApe1 oligomers (2r) and of Atg8-marked puncta/spherical caps (2a) at the beginning (t0) and at the time of maximal expansion (tmax) were measured. The surface of spherical caps was derived from calculating cap height (h = r-(r2-a2)1/2) and equation A = 2πhr for time points t0 and tmax. The change in surface area over time was expressed as the growth rate of the phagophore membrane:
    Determining phagophore expansion frequency, growth rate and maximal size.
    Autophagic membranes (2GFP-Atg8; green) forming on giant preApe1 oligomers (BFP-preApe1; blue) were analyzed at the beginning (t0) and at the time point of maximal expansion (tmax). Corresponding heights (h) and surface areas (A) are calculated for both time points based on the diameter of the preApe1 oligomer (2r) and of the phagophore (2a0 and 2amax).

    Electron microscopy

    Cells corresponding to 60 OD600-units were harvested and directly treated as described previously (Kaiser and Schekman, 1990
    43.
    Kaiser, C.A. ∙ Schekman, R.
    Distinct sets of SEC genes govern transport vesicle formation and fusion early in the secretory pathway
    Cell. 1990; 61:723-733
    Abstract
    Full Text (PDF)
    Scopus (520)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). Overnight potassium permanganate fixed cells were embedded in Epon (Sigma). After total polymerization, ultrathin sections (50-70nm) were mounted on nickel grids. The contrast of samples was increased by 1% (v/v) uranyl acetate (SERVA) and subsequent 0.1% (w/v) lead citrate (Sigma) staining in 0.1 M NaOH (Roth). Grids were imaged using a Jem-2100Plus transmission electron microscope (Joel) equipped with an OneView 4K Bottom camera (Gatan).

    Whole cell extraction, western blot analysis, and quantification

    Cells corresponding to 0.2 OD600-units were collected and lysed by alkaline whole cell extraction using 0.255 M NaOH (Roth) and 1% (v/v) β-mercaptoethanol (Merck). For phosphoprotein analysis, lysis buffer and SDS sample buffer were supplemented with 1 mM NaF and 20 mM β-phosphoglycerol (Sigma). Protein extracts were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting using α-Pgk1 (monoclonal, Abcam), α-GFP (monoclonal, Takara), α-mCherry (polyclonal, Genetex), α-HA (monoclonal, Sigma), α-Atg13 (polyclonal, a gift from Prof. Daniel Klionsky), α-Sec61 (polyclonal, a gift from Prof. Tom Raporport), α-Vac8 (polyclonal, a gift from Dr. Takashi Tatsuta) antibodies. Primary antibodies were visualized using corresponding secondary α-mouse or α-rabbit Dylight800/680 antibodies (Rockland Immunochemicals) and signal intensities were quantified using the Li-COR Odyssey Infrared Imaging system (Biosciences).

    Immuno-purification of Atg8 membranes

    Cells corresponding to 125 OD600-units expressing 2GFP-ATG8 were pelleted, washed and resuspended in 150 mM NaCl (Roth), 50 mM Tris/HCl pH7.5 (Roth), 1 mM MgCl2 (Roth), 10% (v/v) glycerol (Sigma), 1xProtease inhibitor cocktail (Roche). Cell pellets were created in liquid N2 and stored at −80°C. Frozen cell pellets were lysed using a Freezer/Mill (6970EFM, SPEX® Metuchen, NJ; settings T1 = 1 min; T2 = 2 min; T3 = 2 min; cycles, 2; rate, 7). Thawed cell lysates were cleared by centrifugation at 3000 rpm and 12000 rpm at 4°C for 10 min each. Supernatants were incubated with μMACS anti-GFP Microbeads (Miltenyi Biotec) for 1 h at 4°C. Beads were isolated using Miltenyi μ-columns and a MultiMACS® M96 Seperator (Miltenyi Biotec). Columns were washed 5 times with 800 μL 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate (Sigma).
    For analysis by western blotting as shown in Figure S6C, samples were eluted by addition of 150 μL SDS-sample buffer. For analyses by mass spectrometry, on-bead digestion was performed by addition of 100 μL trypsin (300 ng/column, Sigma) in 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate (Sigma) for 1 h at 23°C. Samples were eluted by addition of 150 μL 50 mM ammonium bicarbonate. After overnight incubation at 23°C, reactions were stopped by the addition of 0.1% (v/v) trifluoroacetic acid (Sigma). The aqueous solution was evaporated in a SpeedVac (Eppendorf) and analyzed by Nano-ESI-MS/MS analysis or high-resolution mass spectrometry.

    Mass spectrometry analysis of glycerophospholipids

    Whole cell membrane analysis with Nano-ESI-MS/MS
    Cells corresponding to 10 OD600-units were harvested and homogenized in 300 μL water using a Precellys 24 homogenizer (Peqlab) at 6500 rpm for 30 s. Protein content of the homogenate was routinely determined using bicinchoninic acid. Lipids were extracted using “One-Step Extraction” described in (Özbalci et al., 2013
    79.
    Özbalci, C. ∙ Sachsenheimer, T. ∙ Brügger, B.
    Quantitative analysis of cellular lipids by nano-electrospray ionization mass spectrometry
    Methods Mol. Biol. 2013; 1033:3-20
    Crossref
    Scopus (35)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ): 100 μL homogenate were diluted to 500 μL with Milli-Q water and mixed with 1.875 mL chloroform/methanol 1:2 (v/v) (Sigma) and internal standards (67 pmol PC 17:0-14:1, 81 pmol PE 17:0-14:1, 63 pmol PI 17:0-14:1, 68 pmol PS 17:0-14:1, 77 pmol PG 17:0-14:1, 82 pmol PA 17:0-14:1 (Avanti Polar Lipids)). After the addition of 0.5 mL chloroform and 0.5 mL H2O, the sample was vigorously vortexed and phase separation was induced by centrifugation (800xg for 5 min at 4°C). The lower organic phase was transferred to a second vial and the remaining phases were washed with chloroform and H2O, respectively. The organic phase of the second vial was transferred to a third vial and the organic phase of the initial vial was combined with the aqueous phase of the second vial followed by re-extraction. After phase separation, the organic phases were combined and dried under a stream of nitrogen. Dried lipid extracts were dissolved in 300 μl methanol and analyzed by Nano-ESI-MS/MS as described in (Kumar et al., 2015
    55.
    Kumar, V. ∙ Bouameur, J.E. ∙ Bär, J. ...
    A keratin scaffold regulates epidermal barrier formation, mitochondrial lipid composition, and activity
    J. Cell Biol. 2015; 211:1057-1075
    Crossref
    Scopus (42)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ): 20 μl lipid extract in methanol were transferred into 96-well plates and diluted with 20 μl ammonium acetate (20 mM in methanol). Lipid infusion and ionization was performed using Nano-ESI chips with the TriVersa NanoMate operated by the ChipSoft Software (Advion) using the following settings: sample infusion volume: 14 μl; air volume to aspirate after sample: 1 μl; air gap before chip: enabled, aspiration delay: 0 s; prepiercing: with mandrel; spray sensing: enabled; cooling temperature: 14°C; gas pressure: 0.5 psi; ionization voltage: 1.4 kV; and vent headspace: enabled. Prewetting was done once.
    Mass spectrometric analysis was performed using the QTRAP 6500 (SCIEX) operated by Analyst 1.6.2 with instrument-dependent settings as follows: curtain gas, 20 psi; CAD gas, medium; and interface heater temperature, 100°C. PC was analyzed in the positive ion mode by scanning for precursors of m/z 184 Da at a collision energy of 35 eV. PE, PS, PG, PI, and PA analysis were performed in the positive ion mode by scanning for neutral losses of 141, 185, 189, 277, and 115 Da at 25 eV collision energy. The declustering potential was 100 V. Scanning was performed in a mass range of m/z 650–900 Da and at a scan rate of 200 Da/s. 61 MCA spectra were accumulated. Mass spectra were processed by the LipidView Software Version 1.2 (SCIEX) for identification and quantification of glycerophospholipids. Endogenous glycerophospolipids were quantified by normalizing their peak areas to those of the internal standards.
    Nano-ESI-MS/MS analysis of Atg8 membrane lipids
    Lipids were extracted essentially as described in (Ejsing et al., 2009
    17.
    Ejsing, C.S. ∙ Sampaio, J.L. ∙ Surendranath, V. ...
    Global analysis of the yeast lipidome by quantitative shotgun mass spectrometry
    Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. USA. 2009; 106:2136-2141
    Crossref
    Scopus (601)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ): pellets were resuspended in 200 μL 155 mM ammonium carbonate. After addition of 990 μL 17:1 (v/v) chloroform/methanol and internal standards (s. above), lipids were extracted for 30 min at 20°C using a ThermoMixer C (Eppendorf) at 900 rpm. Phases were separated by centrifugation (16000xg for 5 min at 4°C). The lower organic phase was transferred to a new tube; the upper phase was extracted again with 990 μL chloroform/methanol 2:1 (v/). Combined organic phases were dried under a stream of nitrogen. Dried lipid extracts were resuspended in 200 μL methanol and analyzed by Nano-ESI-MS/MS as described above.
    Whole cell membrane extraction for high-resolution mass spectrometry
    Cells corresponding to 10 OD600-units were washed in 300 μL water, harvested and homogenized using a Tissue Lyser2 (Quiagen) at −180°C with 25Hz for 2 cycles of 1 min.
    Lipids were extracted as described previously for isotope labeled plant tissues (Giavalisco et al., 2011
    24.
    Giavalisco, P. ∙ Li, Y. ∙ Matthes, A. ...
    Elemental formula annotation of polar and lipophilic metabolites using (13) C, (15) N and (34) S isotope labelling, in combination with high-resolution mass spectrometry
    Plant J. 2011; 68:364-376
    Crossref
    Scopus (180)
    PubMed
    Google Scholar
    ). In brief, the homogenate was resuspended in 850 μL of pre-cooled (−20°C) extraction buffer methyl tert-butyl ether (MTBE)/methanol 3:1 (v/v)), containing a 500-fold diluted Splash II Lipidomix (Avantilipids) as an internal standard. Samples were incubated for 30 min at 4°C while shaking at 1500 rpm. Samples were sonicated for 10 min at 0°C in a bath-type sonicator (VWR) and 500 μL phase separation buffer of UPLC-grade water/methanol 3:1 (v/v) was added. The mixture was incubated for 10 min at 4°C shaking at 1500 rpm. Centrifugation, separated samples into three distinct phases. For lipidomic analysis the upper lipid phase was collected and stored at −20°C, until mass spectrometric analysis. The remaining lipid and polar phase were discarded and the solid pellet kept for protein quantification.
    Mass Spectrometric analysis of stable isotope fatty acid-labeled lipids in yeast cells
    For high-resolution mass spectrometric analysis yeast whole membrane lipid extracts or isolated Atg8 membranes were dried in a speed vac concentrator (Eppendorf). After resuspension of samples in either 50 μL or 200 μL UPLC-grade acetonitrile/isopropanol 7:3 (v/v) (VWR), lipids were further solubilized for 5 min at 0°C in a bath-type sonicator (VWR). Following 5 min centrifugation, the cleared supernatant fraction was transferred to 2 mL glass vials with 200 μL inserts (CZT) and placed in an Acquity iClass UPLC (Waters) sample manager at 6°C. The UPLC was connected to a Q-Exactive (QE)-HF high-resolution mass spectrometer, equipped with a heated ESI (HESI) source (Thermofischer). Each sample was injected twice with an injection volume of 2 μL of lipid. Lipids were separated on a 100 × 1.0 mm BEH C8 UPLC column, packed with 1.7 μm particles (Waters). The flow rate of the UPLC was set to 150 μl/min and the buffer system consisted of buffer A (10 mM ammonium acetate, 0.1% acetic acid in UPLC-grade water) and buffer B (10 mM ammonium acetate, 0.1% acetic acid in UPLC-grade acetonitrile/isopropanol 7:3 (v/v)). The UPLC gradient was as follows: 0-1 min 45% A, 1-4 min 45%–25% A, 4-12 min 25%–11% A, 12-15 min 11%–1% A, 15-18 min 1% A, 18-18.1 min 1%–45% A and 18.1-22 min re-equilibrating at 45% A. This leads to a total runtime of 22 min per sample.
    The QE-HF mass spectrometer was operating for the first injection in positive ionization mode and for the second injection in negative ionization mode. In both cases, the analyzed mass range was between m/z 150-1500. The resolution was set to 60.000, leading to approximately 4 scans per second. The acquired gain control (AGC) was set to a value of 3E6, while the maximal ion time was set to 100 ms. The HESI source was operating with a spray voltage of 3.5 kV in positive ionization mode, while 3.2 kV were applied in negative ionization mode. The capillary temperature was 250°C, the sheath gas flow 60 arbitrary units (AU) and the auxiliary gas flow 20 AU at 250°C. The S-lens was fixed on 60 AU. All samples were analyzed in a randomized run-order and the data were analyzed using a targeted approach employing the quan module of the TraceFinder 4.1 software (Thermofischer) in combination with a sample-specific in-house generated compound database. For analysis of stable isotope labeled fatty acid incorporation into distinct lipid species of the main lipid classes, m/z values of either unlabeled (12C fatty acid-containing) or labeled (13C fatty acid-containing; Sigma) lipid species were calculated and areas of resulting peaks were extracted from raw data. Ratios of areas from unlabeled to labeled lipid species were used to determine the synthesis rates of diverse lipid classes.

    Quantification and Statistical Analysis

    Error bars represent SD as indicated in the figure legends. Data were processed in Excel.
    Statistical analysis of differences between two groups was performed using a two-tailed, unpaired t test; ∗, p < 0.05; ∗∗, p < 0.01; ∗∗∗, p < 0.001. Only statistically significant comparisons are indicated in graphs.

    Data and Code Availability

    The lipidomics datasets generated during this study are available at Mendeley data (https://dx.doi.org/10.17632/6hh9dhwpwj.1).

    We use cookies which are necessary to make our site work. We may also use additional cookies to analyse, improve and personalise our content and your digital experience. For more information, see our Cookie Policy and the list of Google Ad-Tech Vendors.

    You may choose not to allow some types of cookies. However, blocking some types may impact your experience of our site and the services we are able to offer. See the different category headings below to find out more or change your settings.

    Manage Consent Preferences

    Strictly Necessary Cookies

    Always active

    These cookies are necessary for the website to function and cannot be switched off in our systems. They are usually only set in response to actions made by you which amount to a request for services, such as setting your privacy preferences, logging in or filling in forms. You can set your browser to block or alert you about these cookies, but some parts of the site will not then work. These cookies do not store any personally identifiable information.

    Functional Cookies

    These cookies enable the website to provide enhanced functionality and personalisation. They may be set by us or by third party providers whose services we have added to our pages. If you do not allow these cookies then some or all of these services may not function properly.

    Performance Cookies

    These cookies allow us to count visits and traffic sources so we can measure and improve the performance of our site. They help us to know which pages are the most and least popular and see how visitors move around the site.

    Targeting Cookies

    These cookies may be set through our site by our advertising partners. They may be used by those companies to build a profile of your interests and show you relevant adverts on other sites. If you do not allow these cookies, you will experience less targeted advertising.
